title: How can a student contribute to society? - Quora

response.answer_text: As the youth of this country, we have an opportunity to contribute to the country in many ways. But before we jump into anything, it is very important that we enhance our own abilities and competence, because just a desire to contribute is not enough. We must have an equanimous mind which allows us to apply ourselves in every situation. But at the same time, we must be do our jobs with full exuberance. This is necessary so that our work is effective enough. Coming to how we can contribute, there are a variety of issues in our country. We need to be observant enough to know what is best needed for the people around is and to enhance their lives. The issues can be divided into local issues and issues which may cover larger territory, maybe, a district, state, or country. Your observation and attention is needed to identify the local issues and innovate ways to solve them. If you look carefully, every district or every state represents a distinct set of problems. However, most of them could be solved if the local issues get sorted out. Because ultimately, the state issues are more or less a reflection or net summation of various local issues. Essentially, I feel it is important to work at the grassroots level. And just not your contribution is enough. We need youth from all over the country to take responsibility. The policies brought on the state and the national level should support the activities taken up on the grassroots. Only then we can see some significant change.

I would say, start by being a compassionate and considerate human being. Just be humane and nice to every one. A smile, a kind word, a helping hand. It doesn't take more than that to make the world a better place. You don’t have to move mountains . Start small, maybe, with family, then friends, college groups and then figure out which groups of people who you have the most compassion for. Is it grieving widows, uneducated street children, homeless people, kids who are bullied, kids who are invisible in the class room etc. Find out the group of people, who when you help, it makes your soul smile, your heart dance with delight. Spend time with those people, volunteer in those groups and you will figure out for yourself your own unique way to contribute to society.

The best thing a student can do is learn to think for him/herself. Choose a major that will leave you employable when you graduate. I still remember… I went from high school straight to college, and I was so impressed with how worldly and wise my professors appeared to be. I ran out of money and dropped out of college. I ended up enlisting in the Army, and after my discharge went back to the same college. Remember those wise professors? I found myself amazed at how parochial and narrow-minded they were after I had real world experience of my own. I also realized how much of the personal political views some of them tried to foist off on students were shaped by their own lack of experience in the real world. If you truly wish to benefit society, start learning to compare differing viewpoints. Don’t be afraid to be the Devil’s Advocate, and for God’s sake, don’t waste time and money by choosing a major like “Gender Studies,” or “African-American Studies.” See how many job offers you get with a BS in those fields.

First, get your own life in order.  You have little credibility with others to tell them how to manage money when you can’t live by a budget. Someone with no experience with children isn’t qualified to tell others who to raise theirs. You have no credibility in how one should alter business operations and social institutions when everything you advocate comes from teachers who likewise never worked in the real world. And the desire to just tear it all down ignores the harm caused by that social disruption and destruction. It dismisses the risk that after you tear it down to rebuild, no one may rebuild (a common issue with eminent domain and civic groups that are destroyed, leaving a hole in the social fabric). It arrogantly assumes that what is built on top of the ruins is better, and if it isn’t better, tends to turn into violence against those who said “let’s not tear it all down, maybe incremental change, it is safer and more controlled”.

A society is only as good as the people who make up that society. It’s quite possible to have a society in which no one is educated (everyone is ignorant) and no one is healthy. It would be a guarantee of failure. A smart society that has the power to do so should ensure that everyone has the best education they are capable of and has the best health care the society is capable of delivering. Clearly, students are extremely important to any society. Education is an investment that ensures the success of a society. So is health.
This is not a joke answer or a sarcastic answer, but a very very serious one. Study.

The best society would not penalise people, working or not, for disabilities or mental illness. This is not their fault. It would transform its idea of beauty from the Platonically idealistic, discarding ‘ideal forms’ for forms that are both realistic and which embrace humanity’s highest aspirations. Life chances would be evenly distributed rather than a concentrated in the 20-65 age range. No longer would people be thrown on the scrap-heap for being ill, disabled, too old etc: rather, there would be a just way of distributing resources to all. This could be implemented in various ways to adjust to society’s changing needs. I am able to define only a good society.
